revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{use American English|date=September 2016}} The German '''Climate Action Plan 2050''' ({{lang-de|Klimaschutzplan 2050}}) is a [[Climate change mitigation|climate protection]] policy document approved by the German government on 14{{nbsp}}November 2016. {{cite web | first1 = Sören | last1 = Amelang | first2 = Benjamin | last2 = Wehrmann | first3 = Julian | last3 = Wettengel | title = Germany's Climate Action Plan 2050 | date = 17 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/factsheets/germanys-climate-action-plan-2050/ | access-date = 2016-11-15 }} The plan outlines measures by which Germany can meet its various national [[greenhouse gas]] emissions reduction goals through to 2050 (see [[#table-greenhouse-gas-policy-targets|table]]) and service its international commitments under the 2016 [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Agreement]]. The [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety]] (BMUB), under minister [[Barbara Hendricks (politician)|Barbara Hendricks]], led the development of the plan. The plan was progressively watered down since a draft was first leaked in {{nowrap|early-May}} 2016. Projections from the environment ministry in September 2016 indicate that Germany will likely miss its 2020 climate target. {{cite web | first1 = Sven | last1 = Egenter | first2 = Julian | last2 = Wettengel | title = Ministry projections highlight risk of Germany missing emissions goal | date = 7 October 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/ministry-projections-highlight-risk-germany-missing-emissions-goal | access-date = 2016-10-07 }} The Climate Action Plan{{nbsp}}2050 should not be confused with an earlier document, the Climate Action Programme{{nbsp}}2020 (''{{lang|de|Aktionsprogramm Klimaschutz{{nbsp}}2020}}''), approved in December 2014 and which only covers the period until 2020. In early 2017 it was agreed that the 2020 Programme would be scrapped. == Climate targets == Germany announced the following official greenhouse gas emissions targets on 28{{nbsp}}September 2010. {{cite book |author1 = Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology (BMWi) |author2 = Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU) |title = Energy concept for an environmentally sound, reliable and affordable energy supply |date = 28 September 2010 |publisher = Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology (BMWi) |place = Berlin, Germany |url = http://www.bmwi.de/English/Redaktion/Pdf/energy-concept,property=pdf,bereich=bmwi,sprache=en,rwb=true.pdf |access-date = 2016-09-15 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161006040920/http://www.bmwi.de/English/Redaktion/Pdf/energy-concept%2Cproperty%3Dpdf%2Cbereich%3Dbmwi%2Csprache%3Den%2Crwb%3Dtrue.pdf |archivedate = 6 October 2016 |df = dmy-all }} {{rp|4–5}} {{anchor|table-greenhouse-gas-policy-targets}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: right" |+ Greenhouse gas policy targets for Germany (with actual figures for 2014) {{cite book |title = The Energy of the Future: Fourth "Energy Transition" Monitoring Report — Summary |date = November 2015 |publisher = Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWi) |place = Berlin, Germany |url = https://www.bmwi.de/BMWi/Redaktion/PDF/V/vierter-monitoring-bericht-energie-der-zukunft-englische-kurzfassung,property=pdf,bereich=bmwi2012,sprache=de,rwb=true.pdf |access-date = 2016-06-09 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160920202129/https://www.bmwi.de/BMWi/Redaktion/PDF/V/vierter-monitoring-bericht-energie-der-zukunft-englische-kurzfassung%2Cproperty%3Dpdf%2Cbereich%3Dbmwi2012%2Csprache%3Dde%2Crwb%3Dtrue.pdf |archivedate = 20 September 2016 |df = dmy-all }} {{rp|4}} |- ! Target !! 2014 !! 2020 !! 2030 !! 2040 !! 2050 |- | align=left | Greenhouse gas emissions (base year 1990) | −27.0% || −40% || −55% || −70% || −80 to −95% |- | colspan="6" align="left" style="font-size:85%" | The 2030 value is also the 2016 Paris Agreement nationally determined contribution (NDC) for Germany. |} Regarding [[European Union]] policy, in October 2009 the [[Council of the European Union]] agreed that the appropriate abatement objective for Europe and other developed economies was 80–95% below 1990 levels by 2050 (consistent with Germany). {{cite book | title = Brussels European Council 29/30 October 2009 — Presidency Conclusions — 15265/1/09 REV 1 | date = 1 December 2009 | publisher = Council of the European Union | location = Brussels, Belgium | url = http://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cms_data/docs/pressdata/en/ec/110889.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-15 }} {{rp|3}} In October 2014 the [[European Council]] endorsed a binding European Union target of an at least 40% reduction in domestic greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 relative to 1990 (less stringent than Germany). {{cite book | title = European Council (23 and 24 October 2014) — Conclusions on 2030 Climate and Energy Policy Framework — SN 79/14 | date = 23 October 2014 | publisher = European Council | location = Brussels, Belgium | url = https://www.consilium.europa.eu/uedocs/cms_data/docs/pressdata/en/ec/145356.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-16 }} {{rp|2}} == Climate Action Programme 2020 == The Climate Action Programme{{nbsp}}2020 (''{{lang|de|Aktionsprogramm Klimaschutz{{nbsp}}2020}}'') is an attempt by Germany to help meet its official 2020 greenhouse gas emissions reductions target after a 'climate gap' had been identified.{{efn|Official translations use the British spelling of programme.}} Projections from 2013 show Germany may miss its 40% reductions target by about {{nowrap|7%-points}} without additional measures. {{cite news | first = Kerstine | last = Appunn | title = The Climate Action Programme – what it's all about | date = 17 November 2014 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/factsheets/climate-action-programme-what-its-all-about | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The first draft of the programme was released in {{nowrap|mid-November}} 2014. How best to control the contribution from coal-fired generation remained controversial, but economy and energy minister [[Sigmar Gabriel]] ([[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]]) dismissed plans aired in his ministry in October 2014 to retire 10{{nbsp}}GW of coal capacity. {{cite news | first = Kerstine | last = Appunn | title = Debate over future of German coal heats up ahead of climate action plan | date = 21 November 2014 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/debate-over-future-german-coal-heats-ahead-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The Climate Action Programme{{nbsp}}2020 was approved on 3{{nbsp}}December 2014. {{cite news | first = Kerstine | last = Appunn | title = Details of new Climate Action Programme | date = 3 December 2014 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/factsheets/details-new-climate-action-programme | access-date = 2016-09-15 }} The official document is available in English. {{cite book | title = The German Government's Climate Action Programme 2020 — Cabinet decision of 3 December 2014 | date = 3 December 2014 | publisher = Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/fileadmin/Daten_BMU/Pools/Broschueren/aktionsprogramm_klimaschutz_2020_broschuere_en_bf.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The most significant part of the new package is a pledge to cut electricity sector emissions substantially by 2020. To do so, the government proposes to cap emissions from the sector at 22{{nbsp}}million tonnes between 2016 and 2020 or 4.4{{nbsp}}million tonnes each year. Once the cap is in place, energy companies will be allocated allowances based on their current emissions. If they cut their emissions by a greater amount, they may be able to sell their surplus to other companies. The package also contains measures to improve energy efficiency and the transport sector. {{cite web | first = Mat | last = Hope | title = Dissecting Germany's new climate action plan | date = 4 December 2014 | website = Carbon Brief | location = London, UK | url = https://www.carbonbrief.org/dissecting-germanys-new-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} [[Environmental movement|Environmental groups]] criticized the package for not going far enough in reducing the reliance on coal-fired generation. {{cite news | first = Madeline | last = Chambers | title = Germany steps up CO2 cuts to meet 2020 climate goals | date = 3 December 2014 | publisher = Reuters | location = New York, USA | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/germany-climatechange-idUSL6N0TN0FN20141203 | access-date = 2016-09-15 }} In December 2015, the government remained confident that its 2020 emissions target will be met through the measures contained in the programme and elsewhere. {{cite press release | author = | title = Germany will achieve its climate targets | date = 18 November 2015 | publisher = The Federal Government | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.bundesregierung.de/Content/EN/Artikel/2015/11_en/2015-11-18-aktionsplan-klimaschutz-2020_en.html | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} However a government report, released on 30{{nbsp}}September 2016, shows that Germany will meet its 2020 greenhouse gas commitments only under "a best case scenario". The report, prepared for the European Union, is available in German. {{cite book | title = Projektionsbericht 2015 — gemäß der Verordnung (EU) Nr. 525/2013/EU | trans-title = Projection Report 2015 — pursuant to regulation (EU) no. 525/2013/EU | language = German | url = http://cdr.eionet.europa.eu/de/eu/mmr/art04-13-14_lcds_pams_projections/projections/envv_vp1a/160928_PB2015_MWMS.final.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-07 }} The analysis projects Germany's greenhouse gas emissions forward for the next 20{{nbsp}}years. A [[PricewaterhouseCoopers|PwC]] report from November 2016 evaluates the economic and ecological effects of the Climate Action Programme{{nbsp}}2020 and finds that the economic benefits outweigh the costs of the proposed measures. {{cite news | title = Climate Action Programme works like a stimulus package | date = 23 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/climate-protection-stimulates-economy-study-grid-fee-disparities/climate-action-programme-works-stimulus-package | access-date = 2016-11-23 }} {{cite book | title = Wirtschaftliche Bewertung des Aktionsprogramm Klimaschutz 2020 — Abschlussbericht | trans-title = Economic assessment of the Climate Action Action Program 2020 — Final Report | language = German | date = 18 November 2016 | publisher = PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) | location = Frankfurt am Main, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/fileadmin/Daten_BMU/Download_PDF/Aktionsprogramm_Klimaschutz/aktionsprogramm_klimaschutz_2020_abschlussbericht_bf.pdf | access-date = 2016-11-23 }} PwC reference: 0.0753813.001. Based on the report, environment minister Barbara Hendricks said in a press release that "the programme will create {{val|430000}} additional jobs and a [[Gross domestic product|GDP]] increase of 1% by 2020". {{cite press release|title=Klimaschutz zahlt sich aus: 430.000 zusätzliche Jobs durch Klimaschutzpaket|date=23 November 2016|publisher=Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB)|location=Berlin, Germany|url=http://www.bmub.bund.de/N53755/|language=German|access-date=2016-11-23|trans-title=Climate protection pays off: 430,000 additional jobs through the climate protection package|author=}} In early 2017 the government agreed to scrap the 2020 plan entirely.https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-germany-politics/german-coalition-negotiators-agree-to-scrap-2020-climate-target-sources-idUKKBN1EX0OW == Development of the Climate Action Plan 2050 == The history of the Climate Action Plan{{nbsp}}2050 is quite involved. The [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety]] (BMUB) is the lead agency for the plan, under the direction of environment minister [[Barbara Hendricks (politician)|Barbara Hendricks]] ([[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]]). A novel [[public consultation]] process was utilized to collect ideas from state and city governments, [[advocacy groups]], and [[citizenship|citizens]] and these ideas were then used to help create the first version. Internal drafts of the plan were leaked three times to the media in 2016, the first in {{nowrap|early-May}}, the second in {{nowrap|late-June}}, and the third in {{nowrap|early-November}}. === Coalition agreement: 2013 === The notion of a climate action plan arose from the coalition agreement between the [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]], [[Christian Social Union in Bavaria|CSU]], and [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] parties in 2013. The agreement stated: {{quote|[I]n Germany we want to define an emissions reduction pathway with a final target of 80{{nbsp}}to 95{{nbsp}}percent lower greenhouse gas emissions compared to 1990 by 2050. We will augment this target with concrete measures, drawn up through a broad dialogue (Climate Action Plan).{{rp|1}}}} === Public consultation: 25 June 2015 – 19 March 2016 === A public consultation with stakeholders began on {{nowrap|25–26 June}} 2015 with a Kick-off Conference in Berlin. {{cite web | title = Hendricks startet Dialog zum Klimaschutzplan 2050 | trans-title = Hendricks launches dialogue on Climate Action Plan 2050 | language = German | date = 25 June 2016 | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/presse/pressemitteilungen/pm/artikel/hendricks-startet-dialog-zum-klimaschutzplan-2050/?tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=3915 | access-date = }} A discussion paper for this exercise was dated 9{{nbsp}}June 2015 and is available in English. {{cite book | title = Climate Action Programme 2050 — Policy paper by the BMUB for the launch of the participation and dialogue process | date = 9 June 2015 | publisher = Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/fileadmin/Daten_BMU/Download_PDF/Klimaschutz/klimaschutzplan_2050_impulspapier_en_bf.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The consultation process involved a series of meetings with [[States of Germany|states]] (''{{lang|de|Länder}}''), [[municipality|municipalities]], associations, and citizens, with delegates selected to represent these various groupings in subsequent forums. {{cite web | title = Dialogue Process — Climate Action Plan 2050 | publisher = IFOK | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.klimaschutzplan2050.de/en/dialogue-process/ | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The process was organized by the [[Wuppertal Institute]] and the dialog agency IFOK. {{cite web | title = IFOK | website = IFOK | location = Bensheim, Germany | url = https://www.ifok.de/en/ | access-date = 2016-11-24 }} Corporate website. {{cite web | title = The German DDPP team in support of the national Climate Action Plan 2050 | date = 15 April 2016 | website = Deep Decarbonization Pathways Project (DDPP) | location = Paris, France | url = http://deepdecarbonization.org/2016/04/the-german-ddpp-team-in-support-of-the-national-climate-action-plan-2050/ | access-date = 2016-09-18 }} The resulting proposals for action were collated and presented at a meeting at the environment ministry (BMUB) on {{nowrap|18–19 March}} 2016. The final report is available in German. {{cite web | title = Ergebnis des Dialogprozesses: Der Maßnahmenkatalog 3.1 | trans-title = Results of the dialogue process: The catalog of measures 3.1 | language = German | publisher = IFOK | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.klimaschutzplan2050.de/ergebnis/ergebnis-des-dialogprozesses-der-massnahmenkatalog-3-1/ | access-date = 2016-09-15 }} {{cite book | title = Maßnahmenkatalog — Ergebnis des Dialogprozesses zum Klimaschutzplan 2050 der Bundesregierung | trans-title = Catalog of measures — results of the dialogue process on the Climate Protection Plan 2050 of the Federal Government | language = German | date = March 2016 | publisher = Wuppertal Institut, ifeu, Öko-Institut, Fraunhofer ISI, IREES, and IFOK | location = Germany | url = http://www.klimaschutzplan2050.de/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Massnahmenkatalog-3-1-final-Ergaenzungen-Anpassungen1.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-15 }} This input was used to help create the first draft of the Climate Action Plan{{nbsp}}2050. The German government also explained its public participation process at the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] ({{nowrap|COP 21}}) on 9{{nbsp}}December 2015. {{cite book | title = Translating Ambition into Action — The German Climate Action Plan 2050 — UNFCCC COP 21 German Side Event, 9 December 2015, Paris – Le Bourget, Conference Centre | date = 9 December 2015 | publisher = Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.klimaschutzplan2050.de/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/KSP-Bund-Side-Event-Dokumentation_Englisch.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-17 }} The design of the consultation process was novel for Germany. An explanatory video from the BMUB is available. {{cite AV media | title = Erklärfilm zum Klimaschutzplan 2050 (mit englischen Untertiteln) | trans-title = Explanatory video on the Climate Action Plan 2050 (with English subtitles) | language = German, English | date = 31 October 2016 | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Bonn, Germany | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WkNm5ZFzPhM&index=10&list=PL8RzGVmZSvAueWwtMuEsHZ8KPKqP1IXR2 | access-date = 2016-11-07 }} === First leaked draft: early-May 2016 === A draft of the plan was leaked to media for the first time in {{nowrap|early-May}} 2016. {{cite news | first = Kerstine | last = Appunn | title = Climate Action Plan 2050: negotiating a path to decarbonisation | date = 23 June 2016 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/factsheets/climate-action-plan-2050-negotiating-path-decarbonisation | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} It was the result of consolidating a long catalog of measures from the consultation process. The leaked plan included proposals for: * [[ecotax|ecological tax reform]] and the internalization of [[externality|environmental costs]] * climate friendly investment * reducing emissions from coal and a [[Fossil-fuel phase-out#Germany|phase-out of coal]] (''{{lang|de|Kohleausstieg}}'') well before 2050 * making both old and new buildings [[carbon neutrality|climate-neutral]] * the digitalisation and electrification of the transport sector * a floor price for carbon and climate-aware investment * a reduction in the numbers of ruminant animals and for the public to eat less meat * the use forests as [[carbon sink]]s and the renaturalisation of [[moorland]]s for the same purpose * the investigation of a new national welfare index * the embedding of climate protection in local and regional public services The plan also suggested a "pluralistic" (meaning diverse groups are represented) commission be established, tasked with developing a coal phase-out plan by {{nowrap|mid-2017}}. Following the leaked document, state governments became increasingly concerned that they were being railroaded into climate change goals that could damage their regional economies. {{cite news | first1 = Silke | last1 = Kersting | first2 = Klaus | last2 = Stratmann | title = States Protest Climate Action Plan | date = 20 May 2016 | publisher = Handelsblatt | location = Düsseldorf, Germany | url = https://global.handelsblatt.com/edition/433/ressort/politics/article/states-protest-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-09-18 }} === Second leaked draft: 21 June 2016 === A draft of the plan was leaked to media for the second time in {{nowrap|late-June}} 2016. The draft was dated 21{{nbsp}}June 2016 and is available for download in German. {{cite book | title = Klimaschutzplan 2050 — Klimaschutzpolitische Grundsätze und Ziele der Bundesregierung | trans-title = Climate Action Plan 2050 — Climate protection policy principles and objectives of the Federal Government | language = German | date = 21 June 2016 | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://images.klimaretter.info/filestore/1/7/7/2/0_05a64be919580a6/17720_c8de73a39d29dbf.pdf?v=2016-06-29+10%3A10%3A09 | access-date = 2016-09-17 }} This is a leaked draft. Unlike the first leak, this draft was compiled after consultation with the economics and energy ministry (BMWi). {{cite news | title = New draft of Climate Action Plan 2050 without clear plan for coal exit or CO2 sector targets | date = 29 June 2016 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/climate-plan-draft-without-clear-coal-exit-time-majority-nuclear-phase-out/new-draft-climate-action-plan-2050-without-clear-plan-coal-exit-or-co2-sector-targets | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The new draft shows that individual sectors may escape specific emissions targets and that an end date for coal-fired generation has been omitted. Earlier versions had contained sector-specific targets for energy, transport, industry, buildings, and agriculture. The energy sector which was previously slated to make a "considerable" contribution is now required to make an "adequate" contribution. Rather than saying that coal-fired generation must "end well before 2050" the new draft emphasizes that "the importance of power production from coal will decrease" and that there will be a "step-by-step reduction". The previous draft stated that the transport sector would need to deliver "disproportionately high" emissions reductions (on account of the poor performance of the sector to date), that has now diminished to an "ambitious" contribution. Other proposals remain, including the development of ecological tax reform. The plan also includes targets for modernizing the heating and cooling systems in buildings, including no new fossil-fueled heating systems in houses after 2030. {{cite news | first = Kerstine | last = Appunn | title = CO2 targets and coal deadline omitted from Climate Action Plan draft | date = 29 June 2016 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/co2-targets-and-coal-deadline-omitted-climate-action-plan-draft | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} The proposal for a Commission on Climate Protection, Growth, Structural Change, and the Completion of the ''Energiewende'' (''{{lang|de|Kommission "Klimaschutz, Wachstum, Strukturwandel und Vollendung der Energiewende"}}'') remains, but now without the specific task of developing a roadmap for the phase-out of coal. The weakening of the plan is also a result of industry associations repeatedly criticizing sector targets and itemized measures, which they fear would harm Germany's economic performance and international competitiveness. === Official draft: 6 September 2016 === An official draft was released on 6{{nbsp}}September 2016 and is available in German. {{cite book | title = Klimaschutzplan 2050 — Klimaschutzpolitische Grundsätze und Ziele der Bundesregierung — BMUB-Hausentwurf vom 06.09.2016 | trans-title = Climate Action Plan 2050 — Climate policy principles and goals of the government — BMUB draft from 9 June 2016 | language = German | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://m.bmub.bund.de/fileadmin/Daten_BMU/Download_PDF/Klimaschutz/klimaschutzplan_2050_entwurf_bf.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} This draft retains a provision for the establishment of a Commission on Climate Protection, Growth, Structural Change, and the Completion of the ''Energiewende''. The content however has been watered down considerably. Concrete emissions reductions targets were removed altogether. The previously leaked June 2016 draft stated that by 2030 "a large majority of newly registered cars" would need to be powered by either electricity or [[biofuel]]s. But the new draft merely states that "the government aims to significantly lower car emissions by 2030" and that electric cars can contribute to that goal. {{cite news | first1 = Sören | last1 = Amelang | first2 = Julian | last2 = Wettengel | title = Ministry avoids concrete targets in weakened Climate Action Plan | date = 8 September 2016 | publisher = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/government-avoids-concrete-targets-weakened-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-09-14 }} [[Environmental movement|Environmental groups]] have become increasingly critical of the plan as each iteration led to a watering down of its climate protection provisions. The [[non-governmental organization|NGOs]] were particularly concerned about the lack of detail concerning a [[Fossil-fuel phase-out#Germany|coal phase-out]]. On 24 September 2016, Greenpeace Germany issued a report critical of the watering down of the results of the consultation process. {{cite press release | author = | title = Greenpeace: Klimaschutzplan 2050 kein Wunschkonzert der Wirtschaftslobby | trans-title = Greenpeace: Climate Action Plan 2050 no wish list of the business lobby | language = German | date = 24 September 2016 | work = Greenpeace | location = Hamburg, Germany | url = https://www.greenpeace.de/presse/presseerklaerungen/greenpeace-klimaschutzplan-2050-kein-wunschkonzert-der-wirtschaftslobby | access-date = 2016-09-26 }} {{cite book | first = Dieter | last = Rucht | title = Der Beteiligungsprozess am Klimaschutzplan 2050: Analyse und Bewertung | trans-title = The participation process for the Climate Protection Plan 2050: analysis and evaluation | language = German | date = September 2016 | publisher = Greenpeace | location = Hamburg, Germany | url = https://www.greenpeace.de/sites/www.greenpeace.de/files/publications/20160922_klima-gutachten_web.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-26 }} === Cabinet deliberations: late-2016 === In {{nowrap|late-2016}}, the plan went to the [[German Chancellery|Chancellery]] (''{{lang|de|Bundeskanzleramt}}'') to coordinate the final version to be agreed by the [[Cabinet of Germany|German cabinet]] (''{{lang|de|Bundeskabinett}}''). Media reports in {{nowrap|late-October}} 2016 suggest a deepening rift between the economics and energy ministry (BMWi) and the environment ministry (BMUB) over the plan and the exit process for coal-fired generation (''{{lang|de|Kohleausstieg}}''). Economy and energy minister [[Sigmar Gabriel]] opposes the setting of a coal exit date before job alternatives for [[lignite]] workers have been determined. {{cite news | first1 = Sören | last1 = Amelang | first2 = Sven | last2 = Egenter | first3 = Julian | last3 = Wettengel | title = Deep divisions persist over German climate plan, coal exit | date = 26 October 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/deep-divisions-persist-over-german-climate-plan-coal-exit | access-date = 2016-10-27 }} A revised draft plan, circulated by the environment ministry on 4{{nbsp}}November 2016, was obtained by ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]''. The plan has become more stringent and now includes passages that had earlier been removed during the negotiations between ministries. The new plan also precludes new coal-fired generation and the expansion of existing [[Open-pit mining|open-pit mines]] and calls on the government to lobby for an EU-wide [[Price floor|floor price]] for auctioned [[European Union Emission Trading System|EU ETS]] emissions allowances. {{cite news | title = Lignite: The endgame has begun | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/firms-call-ambitious-climate-plan-unions-push-e-mobility/lignite-endgame-has-begun | access-date = 2016-11-07 }} {{cite news | first = Michael | last = Bauchmüller | title = Klimaschutzplan des Umweltministeriums: Das Endspiel um die Braunkohle hat begonnen | trans-title = Climate Action Plan of the Ministry of the Environment: The end game around brown coal has begun | language = German | date = 5 November 2016 | work = Süddeutsche Zeitung | location = Munich, Germany | issn = 0174-4917 | url = http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/entwurf-des-umweltministeriums-klimaschutzplan-soll-ende-der-braunkohle-einleiten-1.3235866 | access-date = 2016-11-07 }} On 7{{nbsp}}November 2016, over 40 German companies, including energy suppliers [[EnBW]] and [[MVV Energie]] and network operator [[50Hertz Transmission GmbH|50Hertz]], together with [[Commerzbank]], [[Deutsche Telekom]], [[IKEA]], and [[Hochtief]], are lobbying for a more ambitious program, one which ensures that Germany's [[Paris Agreement]] commitments are met. The companies want sector-specific emissions targets for 2030 and state that "only in this way can new business models and concrete plans for decarbonisation be developed". They want the goal to be the "rapid switch to 100% renewable energy". British economist [[Nicholas Stern]] also backs a more ambitious plan. {{cite news | title = Businesses demand 2030 sector targets for Climate Action Plan 2050 | date = 7 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/firms-call-ambitious-climate-plan-unions-push-e-mobility/businesses-demand-2030-sector-targets-climate-action-plan-2050 | access-date = 2016-11-07 }} {{cite news | first = Michael | last = Bauchmüller | title = Klimaschutzplan: Unternehmen fordern mehr Klimaschutz | trans-title = Climate Action Plan: Companies are demanding more climate protection | language = German | date = 7 November 2016 | work = Süddeutsche Zeitung | location = Munich, Germany | issn = 0174-4917 | url = http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/klimaschutzplan-unternehmen-fordern-mehr-klimaschutz-1.3236712 | access-date = 2016-11-07 }} The original statement from the companies is available. {{cite book | title = Klimaschutzplan muss für Unternehmen Orientierungsrahmen mit klaren Sektorzielen bieten — Erklärung zum Entwurf des Klimaschutzplans 2050 | trans-title = Climate Action Plan must provide companies with a clear framework for sectoral objectives — Statement on the draft Climate Action Plan 2050 | language = German | date = 7 November 2016 | publisher = Foundation 2°, Germanwatch, and B.A.U.M. | url = http://germanwatch.org/de/download/16404.pdf | access-date = 2016-11-07 }} On 8{{nbsp}}November 2016, economy and energy minister Gabriel vetoed the plan amid concerns by trade union [[IG Bergbau, Chemie, Energie|IG BCE]] and supported by the [[:de:Bundesverband der Deutschen Industrie|BDI]] industry group. The draft does not timetable a phase-out for brown coal, notwithstanding Gabriel said he expected brown coal to remain in use past 2040. {{cite news | first = Markus | last = Wacket | title = German economy minister blocks agreement on climate change plan | date = 9 November 2016 | work = Reuters | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/germany-climatechange-idUKL1N1DA042 | access-date = 2016-11-10 }} On 11{{nbsp}}November 2016, [[Reuters]] news agency reports that chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] and ministers Gabriel and Hendricks have agreed on a new draft. {{cite news | title = Government reaches agreement on Climate Action Plan 2050 | date = 11 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/german-government-reaches-agreement-climate-action-plan-2050/government-reaches-agreement-climate-action-plan-2050 | access-date = 2016-11-11 }} {{cite news | first = Markus | last = Wacket | title = Germany lowers CO2 reduction targets for industry: document | date = 11 November 2016 | work = Reuters | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/us-germany-climatechange-idUKKBN136132 | access-date = 2016-11-11 }} === Approval: 14 November 2016 === On 14{{nbsp}}November 2016, the cabinet officially adopted and released the new plan. {{cite press release | author = | title = Climate Action Plan 2050: Cabinet adopts guide to climate neutral Germany | date = 14 November 2016 | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/N53709-1/ | access-date = 2016-11-17 }} {{cite book | title = Klimaschutzplan 2050: Kabinettbeschluss vom 14. November 2016 | trans-title = Climate protection plan 2050: Cabinet decision of 14 November 2016 | language = German | date = 14 November 2016 | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/fileadmin/Daten_BMU/Download_PDF/Klimaschutz/klimaschutzplan_2050_bf.pdf | access-date = 2016-11-17 }} It was overseen by a [[Christian Democratic Union of Germany|CDU]]/[[Christian Social Union in Bavaria|CSU]]/[[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]] [[grand coalition]] [[List of Federal Republic of Germany governments#16th Bundestag|government]], led by [[Angela Merkel]]. The timing allowed environment minister Barbara Hendricks to present the German plan at the [[2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference|COP{{nnbsp}}22]] climate talks held in [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]]. Canada, Mexico, and the US also presented climate action plans. {{cite press release|title=Minister Hendricks: "Paris is working"|date=18 November 2016|publisher=Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety (BMUB)|location=Berlin, Germany|url=http://www.bmub.bund.de/N53744-1/|access-date=2016-11-22|author=}} == Climate Action Plan 2050 == The official Climate Action Plan{{nbsp}}2050 is available in German and runs to 91{{nbsp}}pages. An official summary of the principles and goals underpinning the plan is available in English. {{cite book | title = Climate Action Plan 2050: Principles and goals of the German government's climate policy | date = 14 November 2016 | publisher = Bundesministerium für Umwelt, Naturschutz, Bau und Reaktorsicherheit (BMUB) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.bmub.bund.de/fileadmin/Daten_BMU/Download_PDF/Klimaschutz/klimaschutzplan_2050_kurzf_en_bf.pdf | access-date = 2016-11-17 }} This document is not an extract translated from the official plan. The plan is to be supplemented by a program of policy measures, developed by the German parliament (''{{lang|de|Bundestag}}''), with the first such program to be in place in 2018. Annual reporting will track progress and should facilitate specific policy adjustments where needed.{{rp|6}} === Preamble === The plan begins with a preamble that states that the document is an evolving work in progress and "cannot and does not want to be a detailed masterplan". It adds that there will be "no rigid provisions" and that the plan is technology neutral and open to innovation. The preamble stresses that the government will simultaneously maintain German competitiveness: {{quote|We want to advance the upcoming changes without structural ruptures. It's about using the strength and creativity of the German market economy, as well as the forces of competition to reach existing national, European and international climate protection targets.}} The preamble also reiterates Germany's 2010 climate targets (see [[#table-greenhouse-gas-policy-targets|table]]) and its 2016 [[Paris Agreement]] commitment.{{efn|Germany's 2015 intended nationally determined contribution (INDC) became its nationally determined contribution (NDC) when it ratified the Paris Agreement on 5{{nbsp}}October 2016.}} === Sector targets === Sector targets remained controversial during the development of the plan. Notwithstanding, the official document now specifies sector targets for the first time under a national climate protection policy. The initial sector targets will be subject to a comprehensive impact assessment and consultation and may well be adjusted as a result in 2018. {{anchor|table-greenhouse-gas-sector-targets}} {| class = "wikitable" style="text-align:right; font-size:100%" |+ Sector targets for greenhouse gas emission reductions {{nowrap|for 2030}}{{nnbsp}}{{rp|4}} |- ! align="left" | Sector !! 1990 !! 2014 !! 2030 !! Reduction
(2030 relative 1990) |- | align="left" | Energy || 466 || 358 || 175–183 || 61–62% |- | align="left" | Buildings || 209 || 119 || 70–72 || 66–67% |- | align="left" | Transport || 163 || 160 || 95–98 || 40–42% |- | align="left" | Industry || 283 || 181 || 140–143 || 49–51% |- | align="left" | Agriculture || 88 || 72 || 58–61 || 31–34% |- | align="left" | Other || 39 || 12 || 5 || 87% |- style="font-weight: bold" | align ="left" | Total || 1248 || 902 || 543–562 || 55–56% |- | colspan="5" align="left" style="font-size:85%" | {{plainlist| * Units: million tonnes [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}eq]]. * 1990 and 2014 values are actual. }} |} For comparison, the Paris Agreement [[Paris Agreement#Nationally determined contributions|nationally determined contribution]] (NDC) for Germany is −55% relative to 1990 (which accords with the final cell in the table). {{cite book | title = NDC/INDC Factsheets — Version 4 November 2016 — Metric GWP AR5 | date = 4 November 2016 | publisher = Australian-German Climate and Energy College, University of Melbourne | location = Melbourne, Australia | url = http://www.climate-energy-college.net/files/site1/docs/11/All_NDCFactsheets_UoM-PRIMAP_GWPAR5.pdf | access-date = 2016-11-23 }} === Commission for growth, structural change, and regional development === The plan establishes a commission for growth, structural change, and regional development. But unlike earlier versions, the commission will not be tasked with setting a date for an exit from coal. Instead, the commission will "support the structural changes" resulting from transformation and will "develop a mix of instruments that will bring together economic development, structural change, social acceptability and climate protection". The commission will be based at the economics and energy ministry, but will consult with other ministries, federal states, municipalities, and unions, as well as with representatives of "affected" companies and regions. The commission is scheduled to start work at the beginning of 2018 and to report at the end of 2018.{{rp|4–5}} === EU Emissions Trading System === {{main article|European Union Emission Trading System}} The plan stresses to role of the [[European Union Emission Trading System]] (EU{{nbsp}}ETS) as the primary climate protection instrument covering the energy sector and parts of industry in central Europe. The government wants to strengthen price signaling and will campaign to make the EU{{nbsp}}ETS "effective" at a European level. Earlier provisions to set a floor price for emissions allowances were removed. === Energy sector === {{main article|Energy in Germany|Energiewende in Germany}} The energy sector [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] target for 2030 is {{nowrap|175–183 million}} tonnes [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}eq]] or a reduction of 61–62% relative to 1990. The energy supply must be "almost completely decarbonised" by 2050, with renewables as its main source. For the electricity sector, "in the long-term, electricity generation must be based almost entirely on renewable energies" and "the share of wind and solar power in total electricity production will rise significantly". If "possible and economically sensible", renewable energy will be used directly in all sectors, and electricity from renewable sources will be used efficiently for heating, transport, and industry. The utilization of biomass will be limited and sourced mostly from waste. The plan states that transitioning to a power supply based on renewables while ensuring supply security is "technically feasible". During the transition, "less carbon-intensive natural gas power plants and the existing most modern coal power plants play an important role as interim technologies". The plan states that "the climate targets can only be reached if coal-fired power generation is reduced step-by-step". Moreover, the German government "in its development cooperation does not lend support to new coal power plants". Regions which depend on coal, like the ''[[Lusatia|Lausitz]]'', need special consideration: "we must succeed in establishing concrete perspectives for the future of the affected regions, before concrete decisions on the step-by-step withdrawal from the lignite industry can be taken". Notwithstanding, a coal phase-out for Germany is implied in the plan, environment minister [[Barbara Hendricks (politician)|Barbara Hendricks]] said in an interview on 21{{nbsp}}November 2016. "If you read the Climate Action Plan carefully, you will find that the exit from coal-fired power generation is the immanent consequence of the energy sector target.{{nbsp}}... By 2030{{nbsp}}... half of the coal-fired power production must have ended, compared to 2014", Hendricks said. {{cite news | title = Coal exit is in the Climate Action Plan | date = 21 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/climate-plan-implies-coal-exit-minister-merkel-seeks-4th-term/coal-exit-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} {{cite news | first1 = Susanne | last1 = Götze | first2 = Susanne | last2 = Schwarz | title = Kohleausstieg steht im Klimaschutzplan | trans-title = Coal exit is in the Climate Action Plan | language = German | date = 21 November 2016 | work = klimaretter.info | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.klimaretter.info/politik/hintergrund/22297-hendricks-kohleausstieg-steht-im-klimaschutzplan | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} The plan also establishes a regional fund to foster new businesses in lignite mining regions. The government will need to ensure that EU competition law does not inhibit the operation of the fund. === Building sector === The building sector [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] target for 2030 is {{nowrap|70–72 million}} tonnes [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}eq]] or a reduction of 66–67% relative to 1990. Under the plan, Germany's building stock will be largely carbon-neutral by 2050 and their limited energy needs will be met through renewables. Due to the slow turnover of buildings, the groundwork for this goal must be laid by 2030. The government will invest heavily in programs to implement high energy standards for buildings. Heating, cooling, and electricity supply will be progressively switched to renewables. The government will terminate support programs that rely on fossil fuels by 2020 and switch instead to support programs using renewable systems. The aim is to "make renewables-based systems much more attractive than fossil-fuel-based ones". === Transport sector === The transport sector [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] target for 2030 is {{nowrap|95–98 million}} tonnes [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}eq]] or a reduction of 40–42% relative to 1990. Unlike earlier drafts, the plan does not now set a deadline for all new cars to be emissions free. Rather the plan states that stricter emissions limits for new cars will be set by the European Union and that "the government will advocate [an] ambitious development of the targets" so that its 2030 goal can be met. These cuts will derive from improved efficiencies and increasingly GHG-neutral energy. Such cuts will require "a significant contribution by the electrification of new cars and should have priority". The plan emphasizes the contribution that [[biofuel]]s can make, stating that "in the target scenario, the energy supply of street and rail traffic, as well as parts of air and maritime traffic and inland shipping is switched to biofuels – if ecologically compatible – and otherwise largely to renewable electricity as well as other GHG-neutral fuels". The need to support public transport, rail transport, and cycling is stressed in the plan. The plan states a next step is to determine the framework needed to ensure that new [[powertrain]] technologies and [[Energy carrier|energy forms]] will be adopted at scale. This then "involves the question of when, at the latest, they should be introduced into the market, and what penetration rate they should achieve by what date". === Industry === The industry [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] target for 2030 is {{nowrap|140–143 million}} tonnes [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}eq]] or a reduction of 49–51% relative to 1990. Good progress has been made and, {{as of|lc=yes|2016}}, the sector must reduce its emissions by about another 20%. Notwithstanding, the plan emphasizes the need to maintain international competitiveness: {{quote|With our modernizing strategy for the economy, the correct political framework, and active regional and structural policy that supports structural change, we want to create dependable framework conditions for the German economy, to adjust to this transformational process early, and use the possibilities connected to it.}} The plan continues that, despite the costs and challenges, climate protection could become an "innovation motor" for a modern high-tech economy. The plan acknowledges that some industrial emissions cannot be avoided – for instance, those from steel production or chemical plants. Such emissions should be reduced as far as possible by developing new processes and replacing old ones – or through the use of carbon capture and utilization (CCU) or [[carbon capture and storage]] (CCS). The government will launch a [[research and development]] program to advance these and other low-carbon processes.{{rp|5}} === Agricultural sector === The agricultural sector [[Greenhouse gas|GHG]] target for 2030 is {{nowrap|58–61 million}} tonnes [[Carbon dioxide equivalent|{{CO2}}eq]] or a reduction of 31–34% relative to 1990. The plan acknowledges that agriculture cannot reach zero emissions, due to the biological processes inherent in plant cultivation and livestock farming. Instead the plan will focus on reducing emissions as much as possible and on the more efficient use of resources. About one third of agricultural emissions are due to [[nitrous oxide]] from fertilizer use. The government wants to reduce these emissions through better management and through [[research and development]]. Another one third of emissions derive from ruminant animals. The government will develop a comprehensive strategy to reduce emissions from livestock farming by 2021. The plan states that 20% of agricultural land by 2030 "should be used for [[organic farming]]", compared with 6.3% in 2014. The government also advocates the use of financial instruments under a reformed EU [[Common Agricultural Policy]] to reduce GHG emissions from the sector." === Land use and forestry sector === The land use and forestry sector offers opportunities for [[carbon sequestration]]. The government will prioritize improving the performance of forests as carbon sinks. Sustainable forest management will also be promoted and permanent grasslands and marshes are to be preserved. The expansion of settlements and transport infrastructure is to be reduced to {{val|30|ul=ha}} per day by 2020 and to zero by 2050. === Financial matters === Under the plan, the government will consider how to incrementally revise taxation through to 2050, on the understanding that "environmental taxes and levies can create incentives for ecological economic activity" and that "environmentally related taxes and levies can cost-efficiently trigger climate-friendly economic behavior". The government also intends to reduce environmentally harmful subsidies. In addition, the government will support efforts to reconcile global finance flows with climate protection goals, for instance through its role on the [[G20]] [[Financial Stability Board]]. === Implementation and revision of the plan === The plan is predicated on a gradual transformation, achieved through a learning process involving the scientific community and accompanied by public dialogue.{{rp|6}} It is therefore intended that the plan can and should respond to changing technological, political, and social conditions. The plan will be reviewed every five years to align it with the evolution of Germany's [[Paris Agreement#Nationally determined contributions|nationally determined contribution]] (NDC) under the [[Paris Agreement]]. The first update is therefore slated for {{nowrap|late-2019}} or {{nowrap|early-2020}}. As early as 2018, the government intends to strengthen the plan by quantifying the various emission reduction efforts and their associated ecological, social, and economic impacts. The sector targets may be modified as a result. Annual reporting should help the government to evaluate and adjust its specific climate protection measures in the short-term. == Reactions == Thilo Schaefer, climate and energy expert at the [[Cologne Institute for Economic Research]] (IW) comments that "it looks like the government forgot that the energy sector and industry already participate in the European emissions trading system{{nbsp}}... in the end, it will simply become more expensive for the affected sectors, but they won't save a single extra ton of {{CO2}}{{nbsp}}... because the emissions saved by German sectors can be emitted by other states". {{cite news | first1 = Sören | last1 = Amelang | first2 = Sven | last2 = Egenter | first3 = Susanne | last3 = Götze | first4 = Julian | last4 = Wettengel | title = Reactions to Germany's Climate Action Plan 2050 | date = 14 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/reactions-germanys-climate-action-plan-2050 | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} [[Simone Peter]], co-chair of the [[Alliance '90/The Greens|Green Party]], said "this is not a good plan anymore, it has become an empty shell, because the ministerial colleagues of [environment minister] Hendricks have removed anything that could be of relevance – be it the coal exit, the end of the combustion engine, or a transition in agriculture". [[Klaus Töpfer]], founding director of the [[:de:Institute for Advanced Sustainability Studies|Institute for Advanced Sustainability Studies]] (IASS), said "this plan is certainly not yet capable of securing the German contribution to the Paris Climate Agreement. This will require more work". Regine Günther, director of policy and climate at [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF Germany]], said "today's climate action plan is only a fraction of what is needed. The only plus point: all sectors get precise reduction targets, which WWF welcomes. However, the list of negatives is much longer: there are no appropriate measures to reach those targets. There is also a blank on the issue of coal. The plan completely dropped the urgently needed ban on further extension of open cast mining. The commission on coal will not start until 2018, after the federal elections. A minimum price on carbon is also missing completely. With this plan, the industry and energy lobbies have proven how well placed they are in the economy ministry. With such a plan there can be no ambitious climate protection." [[Ottmar Edenhofer]], a German climate economist and director of the [[Mercator Research Institute on Global Commons and Climate Change|MCC]], criticized the plan. He said economy and energy minister "[[Sigmar Gabriel]] yielded to lobbyists and sadly put short-term interests before long-term interests". {{cite news | title = Climate expert says economy minister bows to lobby | date = 18 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/vw-cuts-23000-german-jobs-putting-jobs-climate/climate-expert-says-economy-minister-bows-lobby | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} {{cite | title = Klimaökonom Edenhofer wirft Gabriel Einknicken vor Lobby vor | trans-title = Climate economist Edenhofer accuses Gabriel of buckling to lobby | language = German | date = 17 November 2016 | work = Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) | location = Frankfurt am Main, Germany | url = The '''GreenScreen for Safer Chemicals''' is a transparent, [[open standard]] for assessing [[chemical hazard]] that supports [[alternatives assessment]] for [[toxics use reduction]] through identifying chemicals of concern and safer alternatives.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heine |first1=Lauren |last2=Franjevic |first2=Shari |title=Chemical Hazard Assessment and the GreenScreen for Safer Chemicals |journal=Issues in Environmental Science and Technology |date=January 2013 |volume=36 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/311370591 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref> It is used by researchers, product formulators and certifiers in a variety of industries, including building products, textiles, apparel, and consumer products.
The GreenScreen prioritizes the avoidance of substances with a high hazard as a [[carcinogen]], [[mutagen]], [[Reproductive toxicity|reproductive toxicant]] or [[Developmental toxicity|developmental toxicant]] or [[endocrine disruptor]] or that are a [[Persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic substances|persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic substance]] (PBT).
== Types of analysis == The GreenScreen protocol is published in a Guidance document that is reviewed and updated regularly. The description here is based upon the Hazard Assessment Guidance Version 1.4<ref>{{cite book |title=GreenScreen for Safer Chemicals Hazard Assessment Guidance for Chemicals, Polymers and Products |date=January 2018 |publisher=Clean Production Action |edition=Version 1.4 |url=https://www.greenscreenchemicals.org/learn/method-documents |accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> An assessment using the GreenScreen has two major outputs: * '''Hazard levels for endpoints''': It characterizes the hazard level of substances from very low to very high across twenty human and environmental health endpoints addressing: ** [[Human health]] - such as cancer and reproductive toxicity ** [[Environmental protection]] - primarily [[aquatic toxicity]] ** [[Physical hazards]] - [[flammability]] and [[Reactivity (chemistry)|reactivity]] ** Environmental fate - [[Persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic substances#Persistence|persistence]] and [[bioaccumulation]] * '''Benchmarks''': It rates substances from highest concern (Benchmark 1) to lowest concern (Benchmark 4)
The GreenScreen process has two levels of analysis: * '''[[GreenScreen List Translator]]''' - a screening method for quickly identifying known high hazard substances using hazard listings from governmental and professional scientific bodies. The screening is available through free online automated tools. * '''GreenScreen Assessments''' - a full toxicological review to fill hazard data gaps and identify safer substances using scientific literature and modeling tools. This assessment is typically done by a trained practitioner.
A full GreenScreen Assessment provides a more complete hazard profile of a substance than a List Translator screening. It involves a detailed review of the scientific literature to attempt to determine hazard levels for all endpoints and calculate a GreenScreen benchmark. It may also use models and studies of analogs where direct data are scarce. Each endpoint hazard level is also assigned a confidence level based on the quality of the data.
== Benchmark scores == The GreenScreen List Translator only can flag chemicals known to be of highest concern. A full GreenScreen Assessment can benchmark chemicals as being of lower concern. The Benchmark scale is:
* BM-1 - Benchmark 1: Avoid - Chemical of High Concern * BM-2 - Benchmark 2: Use but Search for Safer Substitutes * BM-3 - Benchmark 3: Use but Still Opportunity for Improvement * BM-4 - Benchmark 4: Prefer - Safer Chemical * BM-U - Benchmark U: Unspecified Due to Insufficient Data
The assessment requires data for most endpoints in order to give a substance a benchmark of lower concern than BM-1
Benchmark 1 is reserved for substances with a high hazard of any of the following: * [[Carcinogenicity]] (Cancer) * [[Mutagenicity]] * [[Reproductive toxicity]] * [[Developmental toxicity]] * [[Endocrine disruption]] or that are * [[Persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic substances]] (PBT), very persistent toxicants (vPT), very bioaccumulative toxicants (vBT) or very persistent, very bioaccumulative substances (vPvB)
High hazards for other human health endpoints, such as [[neurotoxicity]] and [[respiratory sensitization]], receive a Benchmark 2
This parallels the prioritization schemes underlying various international governmental regulatory programs such as the [[Substance of very high concern]] definition within the [[REACH Regulation]] of the [[European Union]].
== Special cases == '''DG - Data gaps''': Strict guidelines limit the amount of data gaps. Where there are data gaps, the assessment includes a worst case scenario to determine the lowest possible Benchmark score if the data gap were filled with the highest possible hazard. These Benchmarks include a subscript of DG. A chemical that has too many data gaps receives a Benchmark U.
'''TP - Transformation Products''': The assessment also must identify feasible and relevant environmental transformation products and benchmark them. If the Benchmark score is determined by the transformation products, the Benchmark score will include a subscript of TP.
'''CoHC - Chemicals of High Concern''' (polymer residuals & catalysts): Version 1.4 of the GreenScreen added special rules for benchmarking polymers which include analysis of residual monomers and/or catalysts present at or above 100 ppm. If the Benchmark score is determined by one of these chemicals, the Benchmark score will include a subscript of CHoC.
== Applications == GreenScreen Assessments are internally used for research and product improvement by product manufacturers in many industry sectors, including electronics,<ref name="holder_2013">{{Cite book| publisher = Royal Society of Chemistry| isbn = 978-1-84973-723-4| pages = 157–176| editor = R. M. Harrison| editor2 = R. E. Hester| last1 = Holder| first1 = Helen A.| last2 = Mazurkiewicz| first2 = P. H.| last3 = Robertson| first3 = C. A.| last4 = Wray| first4 = C. A.| title = Chemical alternatives assessments| chapter = Hewlett-Packard’s use of the GreenScreen for safer chemicals| location = Cambridge| series = Issues in Environmental Science and Technology| date = 2013}}</ref> building products, textiles, apparel, and consumer products.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Winnebeck |first1=Kathryn |title=An abbreviated alternatives assessment process for product designers: a children's furniture manufacturing case study |journal=Journal of Cleaner Production |date=March 2011 |volume=19 |issue=5 |pages=464–476 |doi=10.1016/j.jclepro.2010.10.008 |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959652610003999?via%3Dihub}}</ref> For example [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] is using GreenScreen framework and similar approaches to find safer materials in its products and processes<ref>Rob Guzzo, Mike Werner, Art Fong, Lida Tan, Thomas Ebert (September 2016). [https://www.apple.com/environment/pdf/Toxicology_in_Material_Selection_Sept2016.pdf “Integrating Toxicological Assessments in Material Selection for Apple Products”]. Apple. Retrieved October 2018.</ref>.The GreenScreen is also referenced publicly by sustainability standards in several of these industries, including the Health Product Declaration Standard (HPD)<ref>{{cite web |title=HPD Open Standard |url=https://www.hpd-collaborative.org/hpd-open-standard/ |website=HPDC |publisher=Health Product Declaration Collaborative |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>, Portico<ref>{{cite web |title=Help Center: How are products scored? |url=https://portico.healthymaterials.net/help/46-how-are-products-scored |website=Portico |publisher=Healthy Building Network |accessdate=3 October 2018}}</ref>, Building product disclosure and optimization - material ingredients credits in the [[US Green Building Council]]'s [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] program<ref>{{cite web |title=Building product disclosure and optimization - material ingredients |url=https://www.usgbc.org/credits/new-construction/v4/material-%26-resources |website=EED BD+C: New Construction v4 - LEED v4 - Materials & Resources |publisher=US Green Building Council |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>, the International Living Future Institute's Living Product Challenge<ref>{{cite web |title=Living Product Challenge Standard V 1.1 |url=https://living-future.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Living-Product-Challenge-1-1.pdf |website=Living Product Challenge Certification |publisher=International Living Future Institute |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref> (related to the [[Living Building Challenge]], and by various governmental bodies. {{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
The GreenScreen standard is developed, maintained and published by [[Clean Production Action]] (CPA), a non profit organization, based in the United States. CPA publishes the GreenScreen as an open standard which anyone can utilize. To make a public claim using a GreenScreen Benchmark, however, the GreenScreen assessment must be completed by a Profiler licensed by CPA.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
== Related standards == The GreenScreen has substantial overlaps with the [[Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals]] (GHS) and the criteria of the US EPA’s [[Design for the Environment]]. It differs from GHS, however, in some significant ways. GreenScreen has a lower threshold of analysis. GreenScreen includes endocrine activity, addresses PBTs more comprehensively and considers environmental transformation products. GreenScreen also requires and provides guidance for addressing data gaps. GHS, on the other hand, covers more physical workplace hazards then the GreenScreen and provides guidelines for identifying hazards across languages with icons. This reflects the GHS focus on workplace safety and communications.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
The [[Cradle to Cradle]] (C2C) Product Certification program includes a hazard screening protocol that is similar to the GreenScreen and GHS in many ways.The C2C analysis divides endpoints differently and is integrated into a product certification. There is not a standalone public assessment of individual substances.
These programs have been the subject of analysis evaluating the relationships, differences and opportunities for harmonization.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Heine |first1=Lauren |title=Material Health Evaluation Programs Harmonization Opportunities Report |url=https://www.usgbc.org/sites/default/files/material_health_evaluation_programs__harmonization_opportunities_130819.pdf |website=USGBC Resources |publisher=US Green Building Council |accessdate=6 June 2018}}</ref>
